4.1 Word Groups and Meaning

* This sub-point provides an overview of the importance of analyzing word groups (such as phrases and idioms) in biblical exegesis. It explains how analyzing the meaning of word groups can provide insights into the broader meaning of a text.

4.2 Word Groups and Collocation

* This sub-point discusses the importance of analyzing collocations, or the way in which words are frequently used together, in biblical exegesis. It explains how analyzing collocations can aid in understanding the meaning of individual words and phrases.

4.3 Word Groups and Formulae

* This sub-point discusses the use of formulaic language in the Bible, such as recurring phrases and patterns of speech. It explains how analyzing formulae can provide insights into the cultural context and rhetorical devices used by biblical authors.

4.4 Word Groups and Structure

* This sub-point discusses the relationship between word groups and the larger structure of a biblical text. It explains how analyzing the structure of a text can aid in understanding the meaning of individual words and phrases.

4.5 Word Groups and Genre

* This sub-point discusses the relationship between word groups and the genre of a biblical text, such as narrative or poetry. It explains how the analysis of word groups can differ depending on the genre of the text.

4.6 Word Groups and Intertextuality

* This sub-point discusses the relationship between word groups and intertextuality, or the way in which biblical authors drew on earlier texts and traditions. It explains how analyzing intertextuality can provide insights into the meaning of individual words and phrases.

* This sub-point discusses the phenomenon of polysemy, or the way in which a word can have multiple meanings within a semantic field. It explains how analyzing polysemy can aid in understanding the meaning of individual words and phrases.

5.6 Semantic Fields and Cultural Context

* This sub-point discusses the relationship between semantic fields and cultural context. It explains how analyzing the cultural context in which a biblical text was written can aid in understanding the meaning of individual words and phrases within a semantic field.

6.5 Word Pairs and Irony

* This sub-point discusses the use of irony, or the use of words to convey the opposite of their literal meaning, in biblical exegesis. 7.1 Semantic Domains in Biblical Exegesis

* This sub-point provides an overview of semantic domains and their relevance to biblical exegesis. It explains how analyzing the semantic domain of a word can aid in understanding its meaning and how it is used in a particular context. It also discusses how semantic domains can help identify patterns of meaning and usage across a range of biblical texts.

7.2 Identifying Semantic Domains

* This sub-point discusses methods for identifying semantic domains in biblical texts. It explains how to use lexical databases, concordances, and other tools to identify groups of words that share a common semantic field. It also covers the importance of considering the cultural and historical context in which the texts were written in order to understand the full range of meanings associated with a given semantic domain.

7.3 Mapping Semantic Domains

* This sub-point discusses techniques for mapping semantic domains in biblical texts. It explains how to use tools like semantic networks and hierarchical structures to visualize the relationships between words in a semantic domain. It also covers the importance of considering the role of individual words within a domain and how they contribute to the overall meaning of the text.

7.4 Theological Implications of Semantic Domains

* This sub-point explores the theological implications of analyzing semantic domains in biblical texts. It explains how identifying and analyzing semantic domains can help shed light on key theological concepts and themes in the text. It also covers the importance of considering the broader theological context in which the texts were written in order to understand the full range of meanings associated with a given semantic domain.

7.5 Practical Applications of Semantic Domains in Biblical Exegesis

* This sub-point provides practical examples of how semantic domains can be used in biblical exegesis. It covers topics like the use of semantic domains in preaching, teaching, and scholarly research. It also discusses the potential pitfalls of relying too heavily on semantic domains and emphasizes the importance of balancing this approach with other methods of biblical interpretation.
